docs.snippet: CHICAGO, March 1 When it became apparent late Tuesday night that Jane M. Byrne really had toppled Mayor Michael A. Bilandic and the once-invincible Chicago Democratic machine, the shock of initial incomprehension was almost as......
docs.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, March 1 When it became apparent late Tuesday night that Jane M. Byrne really had toppled Mayor Michael A. Bilandic and the once-invincible Chicago Democratic machine, the shock of initial incomprehension was almost as...
docs.abstract: analysis of Byrne's victory; Bilandic had backing of ususal array of city's power elite--not only Dem machine forces but also virtually whole business and labor establishment--and more than $1 million in financing; Byrne had little organized support and less than $200,000 financing; most observers agree that widespread but much overlooked accumulation of discontent among ordinary people, fueled by yrs of arrogance and disregard from City Hall, brought near-record outpouring of blacks, women, independents and others to regis their protests at primary election; criticism over Bilandic's handling of recent snow storm also cited as factor (M)

headline.main: Defeat of a Political Machine; Years and Layers of Discontent in Chicago Voters Surfaced in the Balloting Against Mayor Bilandic News Analysis Accumulation of Discontent 'More Than the Snow'

byline.original: By DOUGLAS E. KNEELAND Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: The State University of New York will require nearly $1 billion in financing over the next decade to complete a number of planned construction projects and to replace a large inventory of deteriorating equipment, according to state and university ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The State University of New York will require nearly $1 billion in financing over the next decade to complete a number of planned construction projects and to replace a large inventory of deteriorating equipment, according to state and university officials.
docs.abstract: SUNY and state officials rept univ needs nearly $1 billion over next decade to complete planned construction projects and replace large inventory of deteriorating equipment; Assemblyman Arthur J Kremer says officials are going to make every effort to avoid tuition increase but also says univ must establish new priorities and determine which campuses get money; univ officials outline some of planned construction and campuses involved; trustees bd says it is prepared to raise tuition by $150 for freshmen and sophmores if it cannot obtain $9 million from state to cover debt service and other critical requirements (S)

headline.main: State U. Is Said to Need $1 Billion; Warns of Budget Gap
